text: - Hi, this is Shashi Prabhakar,

Director of Partner
Solution Architect at AWS.
And with me we have Mike Morris, CTO
of AWS Premium Partner, Effectual.

We are here to talk about
migrating VMware workloads
to native AWS services.
Mike, can you share how Effectual was able

to meet our customer's business
outcome on a tight timeline?
- Yeah, absolutely.

So the customer in this
case is a large customer
in the real estate industry.

So they came to us with
a need to migrate out
of their VMware environment
for both their production and DR.
So they had a mix of legacy systems
and some more modern systems,

and they had recently
grown through a number

of acquisitions, which
had kind of led to a bit
of infrastructure sprawl.

So documentation was kind of
hit or miss in some places,

but, you know, they also had
this additional challenge
of having a very accelerated timeline.

It was just over 60 days
to where they needed
to exit their platform

and be running fully within
the AWS cloud platform.

- Okay. So what I captured
is, speed was needed.

- Yes.
- Complexity was there.
- Yep.
- And then it was pretty large migration.

So what strategy did you
apply to plan on this?
- Yeah, great question.
So we do a lot of migrations
and we leverage a number of AWS tools.

AWS application discovery
service is a great one.

So we use that to do
overall network discovery,
help us with dependency mapping
and a lot of the migration wave planning

and that kind of thing
we use Migration Hub for.

We also leverage years of
experience doing these kind

of complex migrations from
just about every platform
out there to AWS Cloud.
- That's great to know.
So now that planning is done,
now the time to actually migrate,
what was the strategy to do the migration?
- Yeah, great question.
So due to this kind

of really accelerated migration
timeline, we mutually agreed

to leverage a simplified
migration strategy.

So if you're familiar with
the six Rs, we had kind
of slimmed those down to three strategies.

So they were retire,
rehost and replatform.
So let's talk about the retirement.

So the customer's environment
first, looking here, you know,

we kind of broke it down
into one of four buckets.
So they had application VMs.

This was a mix of some
off the shelf software

as well as a couple in-house
developed pieces of software.

They had a number of databases,
you know, the majority
of 'em were supporting applications.

They also had some BI and
and reporting databases.
They had quite a bit of document data.

- Okay.
- And, you know,

this was a mix of kind
of user documentation,

but also things like they had
a document management system
and then they had some cold data storage.

This was mostly data that they
kept for compliance reasons.
So as we kind of look through, you know,

our three strategies here, as
far as retirement, you know,

they looked through, they
had some legacy applications

that they were able to just
quickly cut off the list.
They'd been running for a while.
No one was really using them.
So, you know, there were probably six
or seven applications,
we were able to just instantly say, hey,
this is gonna be retired.

From there, we kind of get
into our rehost and replatform.

So from rehost, you know,
our application VMs,

you know, went to Amazon EC2,
so that was a little bit more
of a lift and shift.

Databases, however, we employed
two different strategies.

So in this hybrid strategy,
the legacy databases

or things were a little
more specialized, maybe came

with some commercial
off the shelf software.

Those also were moved to
EC2 for some of the things
that they developed themselves

and other applications
where it was supported,

which was really most of
their production environment.

You know, we moved these
over to Amazon RDS.
So they were able to leverage a lot

of the operational efficiencies
of using RDS as a platform.
From there, documents.
So this was, you know, for the most part,

user documents went over
to FSX for the stuff

that was accessed all the
time, as well as the things out
of their document management system.

But we also had, you
know, some archive data
that we were able to leverage S3
to provide a significantly reduced cost,

but still give users access
through a file gateway in,

you know, a way that they
were comfortable with.
And then finally on the cold storage side,
this all went into S3.

So there were a number of
tiers we were able to utilize.

Glacier was a great place, a
very, very cost effective way
to take a lot of this old archive data

and retain it without it
costing a lot of money.
- So that's great to know,
like you are using multiple tiers of S3.

And then you are also
using managed service,
like Amazon RDS.

So what was the cost
optimization we are talking here?
And I also heard retirement, right?

Like there were a few legacy
applications, got retired.
So did you see any cost optimization,
coming through this cycle?
- Yeah, we definitely did.
And we also employed some strategies

around reserved instances
and savings plans.

And, you know, we did
some server right sizing

as we were doing the
migration, you know, as part of
that initial evaluation process, you know,

when they had a number of
things in their environment
that were kind of built oversized just
because of the way they were, you know,
utilizing hardware before.

So we were also able to
do a lot of that, right,
sizing step during the migration.
- Yeah, plus the operational heavy lift,
like using a managed service like RDS,
I'm hoping operational side
of cost optimization comes in the play.
- Absolutely. Absolutely.

- And to the next question,
which I had something similar,

like how did you enable the
customer to operate in AWS?
- Yeah, yeah.

You know, their teams
were very experienced

with VMware, but they
were kind of new to cloud
and new to AWS.

So one of the strategies
that we employed actually
with a fair number of our customers is,

using our managed services
to the environment with them.
So this removes a lot

of the operational load
from their teams, you know,

all the day-to-day care and
feeding of the environment.
So it'll freeze up time for their team

to initially focus on
training and upskilling on AWS
and really learning all about the things
that AWS Cloud has to offer.
So, you know, as they kind of learn

and upscale, you know,
customers will frequently take

on some tasks, but what
we found is they see a lot

of value in continuing that
managed services option
because it allows them a lot more agility.

You know, they're much more
quickly able to respond
to business needs, you know,
get involved in strategic initiatives

because they've really
freed up quite a bit
of time, offloading things like backups

and patching, monitoring of
the environment, you know,

OS troubleshooting and
those types of things.

- Yeah and plus, it also
set them successful,
that long term IC.
- Absolutely.
It's a partnership and, you know,

we really keep these
partner type relationships
with our customers,

you know, throughout,
you know, the entire,
we'll restart that.

You know, we really do
see customers continue

to leverage our managed
services long term.

You know, they see a lot of
value in that partnership

and helping them really stay
on top of the newest trends
and as they go

through their phase two
modernization journey, you know,
we're there to assist them along the way.

- Oh actually, I was wanting
to touch on the modernization.

So how do you foresee the
modernization journey?

In this case, it was
a very tight timeline,
so I understand the velocity was needed,

but how do you connect
with the modernization?
- Yeah, yeah.
We did kind of a fast follow with a few

of their internal applications
to modernize into a mix
of serverless with Lambda as well
as some containerized pieces.
So they have a couple applications,
they've gone through that.

There are a number of
additional ones that we're kind

of working through
right now to see exactly

where those should land from
an architecture perspective.
But you know, we were able
to hit this very tight migration timeline
of just over 60 days
and are now kind of on that phase two

of modernization into the
broad list of services
that AWS has to offer.
- That's great to know.
Yeah, I mean in this case,

definitely the speed was needed,
so it totally makes sense

to kind of do the migration and
then the modernization plan.

Mike, thanks a lot for sharing
this customer migration story

and the outcomes you were
able to bring to them.
- Yeah, yeah.

Outcomes are a huge
focus for us at Effectual

and, you know, that's what
we're always aligning to

and tying back to is, what
are the business outcomes
that the customer needs.
So it's been great. Thanks for having me.
- Thank you for joining us today.
